Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A: injury<n><n>B: beauty<n><n>C: late<n><n>D: mistakes<n><n>E: annoyed<n><n>Answer: <n><n>##### Explanation: <n>The first case that happens when a grooming takes more than 12 hours is that the groomer will get injured. The client can complain and request for compensation and the next appointment will take place. <n><n><n><n>When a second groomer is hired, an appointment is created with the start times, the appointment duration, and the end time. The appointment duration is when each groomer works on a client. Each groomer is responsible for 6 clients at a time. Each groomer will be assigned 30 appointments while one new appointment is created for each client each hour. Each appointment has many groomers working for it simultaneously, the number is dependent on the duration of the grooming.<n><n>When a grooming takes longer then it was expected, one of the groomers are injured and another groomer will be assigned to the client. When multiple groomers are assigned to a client, the client is not happy and a late fee has to be applied. A late fee is given by the client to the groomer as compensation.<n><n>When a third groomer joins the team, three appointments are created for each client, and the next appointment starts when the last appointment ends. When a grooming takes more time than the expected time, the next appointment is delayed. If more groomers leave, more clients will be delayed. More groomers will be hired and new appointments will be created. Each appointment is scheduled and there is no reason to delay another one. If more groomery joins, there is no reason for client to delay because a grooming takes more hours.<n><n><n><n>##### Test data:<n><n>Input: 	Each groomer requires 6 clients to groom at a time.<n>	Number of groomers: 3 groomers, which means each groomer takes the responsibility to do 30 appointments at the same time.<n><n>Output: 	30 appointments for each groomer.<n><n>Input:  Number of groomers:<n>3<n>	Number of appointments per groomer is:<n><n>Output:	The number of appointments per groom: 10, which means for every groomer there are 10 appointments at the

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) **(C)**<n><n>***BAD**: A, B, B, D<n>***GOOD**: C, B<n><n>### Instructions:There are a group of friends, who are all reading a book. They will start reading on page 1 and will not skip any. However, after each page, they will go to the back of the book and start reading on page 2. They will continue to do this for a few pages. After each person has finished, they may discuss the book, but only for 3 minutes. They may read the book again without going to the back of the page. After they have talked for 3 minutes, they will leave and the next person will begin. The last person in the group will mark the current page number in the book, and then place it back in circulation.<n><n>### Note:<n>*Every person reads the book every time through.*<n>*Every person writes the page number in the book.*<n>*Every person reads 3 pages after the discussion.*<n><n>### Demand: How many different combinations do you think are possible? How many ways can Alice participate if she reads the book for the first time?  How many ways can Alice pass the book to her friend, but read it herself before and after? Write a function for how many ways Alice can participate.<n><n>### Response<n>A) **(NOTE Difficulty)**<n><n>***GOOD** : 4! X 5! x 6!<n><n>### Input<n>***BAD** : 4! x 5!x 6! X2<n><n>### Demossion<n>Input: Write a function for how Alice can participate. Alice may pass the book or she may read it herself<n><n><n>### Disscussion<n>Input: Write a formula for how Alice can participant<n><n><n><n><n>

If the time in Los Angeles is 8 hours behind New York time, what time is it in Paris?<n>Answer: Paris is 12:00<n><n>### Instructions: How long would a rocket have to stay in space for an astronaut to gain the same effect as if he went to the equator and ran around the earth 20 times? (Assume all times will be the same, even at the equator.)<n><n>### Solution<n>The speed at the equator is 29,830 kilometers per hour. If we assume a constant velocity and no deceleration or acceleration along the journey, then, if an astronaut runs at an average speed of 21 kilometers every hour running in a circle around the Earth, the astronaut would need to run a distance of 6,35,20,000 meters around the Earth. As we know, the circumference of the Earth is a little more than 40,000 kilometers, thus, the astronaut would run around the Earth 428,804 times in order to complete the required distance. As such, the answer to the question is that it would take 33,300 times longer for the astronaut to gain the effective weight he would gain by going from Earth to the equator than if he ran around the Earth 20 times.<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: leg B: garment C: torso D: body E: road<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:You are given n number of houses, each in the form of a two-integer sequence. Each house is represented by the pair (price, numberrooms), where price is a nonnegative integer and numberrooms the number of rooms. The goal is for you to find, for each pair (price, numberofrooms), the house that contains the highest numberofrooms. <n><n>Assumption: Houses have the same price. <n><n><n>Input Format: Integers numberofrooms,price separated by a space.<n><n>Constraints:  1<= price<=10^18<n><n>Output: A list of sorted indexes of the pairs (price,numberofrooms).<n><n>### Example Input:<n><n>3 2<n><n>Example Output:<n><n>0, 1<n><n>### Constraints:<n><n>```java<n>public class Solution {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) { <n>        //System.out.println(solution.findHouse(new int[]{1, 4}, 2));<n>    }<n><n>    public int[] findHouse(int[] price, int numberofrooms) {<n>        int current = 0;<n>        int currentmin = -1;<n>        int highest = 0;<n>    <n>        int min = 1;<n>    <n>        for (int i = 0; i < price.length; i++) {<n>            if (min > (min+(numberofrooms-1))/2) {<n>                if (i == price.length - 1) {<n>                    min = (Math.min(min + (numberofrooms - 1)/2, min + (numberofrooms))/2<n>                 + price) / price[i];<n>                }<n>                if (Math.min(Math.min(min+(numberofrooms - 2))/2,<n>                 Math.min(min+(1 + numberofrooms - 2)/2))<n>                 >= Math.min(Math.max(min+(numberofroom - 1))/2,<n>                Math.max(min+(1 +numberofrooms - 0) /2) {<n>                    <n>                //        break;<n>                }<n>                int diff = Math.abs(min-(price[i]-current));<n>                if (diff >= current) {

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: happiness D: being entertained E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct response is choice (D).<n><n>### Inputs for this question<n><n>- Task/Instructions - Demonstration: <div class="inst">**Input: The difference in <b>ages</b> between Richard and Hurley <b>is 20</b>. If Hurley is <b>14 years old</b>, what are their combined <b>ages</i> 40 <i>years</i> <b>from now</b>?</div><n>- Input: Answer - Demonstration <div markdown="1" class="inst" aria-hidden="true">Answer: <b>128</b></div><n>- Input/Output: Answer - Response <div markdown="2" class="inst" id="response" aria-hidden="false">The correct response is choice <b>D</b>.<br> <br> Inputs for this question</div><n><n>### Output for this question<n><n>`inst` class attributes are a bit-hacked solution. This means that they are a bit messy because we are using them in 3 ways as an input/an output/pseudo response. See the answer below.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>```<n><div id="input" markdown="1" data-reactid="28"> The correct response is choice <span data-reactid="32">D</span>.<n>                                                        </div><n><button id="enter">Enter</button><n><button type="submit">Submit</button><n><div class="inst" ariahidden="true"><n><div class="input" data-reactid=".inst:nth-of-type(29)"><n>Richard's <b>age</b></div>   <span data-react-type="checkbox" data-reactid=.inst:nth-of_type(33)>20</span><n></div><n>```<n><n><p>&nbsp;</p><n><n><p>&ensp;</p><n><n>&nbsp;<n><n><p>&bull;</p>

Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>This is a task in which we need to answer the question given the choice that the student chooses from a number of items.<n><n>I am considering the following items: Pocket (I), shower (I), chemist (I), drug store (E), shaving kit (E).<n>- A is an item that would only go in a shower (I), which is eliminated.<n>- B would not go in a pocket (I) or in a drug store (E), making it eliminated.<n>- C would not go in a chemist (I) or in an item that is not a choice (E, shaving kit), as well as being unlikely to store a double edge.<n>- D would not go in a shaving kit (I and E), neither a shower (I) or a drug store (E). (Note: A shaving kit has a razor and a shaving cream).<n>- E would not go in a drug store (I) but is likely to store a razor of some nature in a shaving kIt (I and E).<n><n>- Therefore, A = Pocket (I), and E = Shaving kit (I & E)<n><n>### Solution<n><n>A is a choice that would go into the pocket. This is because it would be in the item that would go in the shower(I).<n><n>### Input<n><n>This is a word problem wherein we need to solve. So we need to read and determine the quantity and the item.<n><n>In the question "If 99 cents equalled four dollars, what would a $45 item cost" we are given two equations as base. These are<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Examplsation:<n>In determining the quantity in the question "12 books each priced $2.50 and a second book priced 9.60, how much would the total cost be?" we are given the following equation:<n><n>Now we need determine what the variable is in the previous question.<n>Note that if we use dollars, we see we are limited to having 4 decimal digits, as they only go up to four digits for decimal points. Your father’s height was measured to be 75 inches. Your family physician has recommended that your height increase by 3 inches each year from your 9th to your 20th birthday. In the 3rd year of your program the doctor orders you to eat an additional 250 grams of red meat each day to accelerate your height increase, bringing it to 12 inches each year to help you reach your goal. You are not able to meet this requirement and miss 38 days due to illness. The doctor orders you to eat the red meat until your 16th birthday. The doctor warns that no additional meat is safe. How tall will you be after your 20th year?<n>Answer: 77 Inches.<n>
